section.title: Introduction
section.para: &ansible; is a suite of tools for managing and provisioning data centers via definition files. This article describes how to run &ansible; on the &productname; (&productnameshort;).

listitem.para: python3-lxml and python3-rpm packages are required for &ansible; to interact with &libvirt; and gather package facts. The kernel-default-base package does not contain the required drivers for multiple &nm; or nmcli operations, such as creating bonded interfaces. Replace it with kernel-default:
listitem.screen: &prompt.root;transactional-update pkg install python3-rpm python3-lxml kernel-default -kernel-default-base &prompt.root;shutdown -r now

section.title: Operation via SSH
section.para: Because &ansible; is running inside a container, the default localhost environment is the container itself and not the system hosting the container instance. Therefore, any changes made to the localhost environment are made to the container and are lost when the container exits.
Instead, &ansible; can be targeted via an SSH connection at the host that is running the container, namely host.containers.internal, using an &ansible; inventory similar to the following example:
section.screen: alhost_group: hosts: alphost: ansible_host: host.containers.internal ansible_python_interpreter: /usr/bin/python3
section.para: An equivalent alphost default inventory item has also been added to the container's /etc/ansible/hosts inventory, which can be used by the ansible command-line tool. listitem.para: SSH keys are created using ssh-keygen.
The public SSH key is included in the .ssh/authorized_keys file for the target user.

important.para: The preferred method is to use a non-&rootuser; account that has passwordless sudo privileges. Any operations in &ansible; playbooks that require system privileges need to use the become: true setting.

tip.para: SSH access can be validated with the ssh localhost command.
